channel.title: I feel dumb
channel.description:
Trying to portforward on a new router that I never have before.
It is D-Link DIR 815.
-The firewall is off on the computer. -The ip address is set to the right number -the port is set to 43594 with the correct settings
However, the port is still not open. Anything I should try or that I am forgetting?

item.title: I feel dumb
item.dc:creator: @matzie matzie
item.description:
@matzie wrote:

[quote=“marcbob, post:40, topic:547423”][quote author=matzie link=topic=666328.msg4458937#msg4458937 date=1416456812]
Are you 100% sure that server runs on port 43594? :l
[/quote]
Yeah haha I made sure[/quote]
can you connect? locally or through external IP?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @marcbob marcbob
item.description:
@marcbob wrote:

matzie:

Are you 100% sure that server runs on port 43594? :l

item.title: I feel dumb
item.dc:creator: @marcbob marcbob
item.description:
@marcbob wrote:

[quote=“Zymus, post:37, topic:547423”]Yes, here’s what the output should have looked like:

TCP 10.12.14.58:57817 10.12.146.20:43594 ESTABLISHED

where the left ip is the local address, and the right is the remote port[/quote]
I have a feeling it’s something with the internet where I am currently living. Back home I was able to portforward with no issue. I guess instead of getting donations then buying a vps I’ll just have to get the money for a vps first somehow. Thanks for offering help Zymus and everyone else! Hopefully I can find a reasonably priced one

Read full topic

item.title: I feel dumb
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Yes, here’s what the output should have looked like:

TCP 10.12.14.58:57817 10.12.146.20:43594 ESTABLISHED

where the left ip is the local address, and the right is the remote port

Read full topic

item.title: I feel dumb
item.dc:creator: @marcbob marcbob
item.description:
@marcbob wrote:

[quote=“Zymus, post:35, topic:547423”][quote author=marcbob link=topic=666328.msg4458845#msg4458845 date=1416427325]

Are you checking via http://canyouseeme.org/ ?

Yes that’s what I’m using

With any of these checkers, it tries to make a connection to the server that’s running. If the server isn’t running, it will always fail. So that’s what I would check. After that, make sure that you added a firewall rule to allow incoming connections on the correct port for the java process as well.

The server was always running when I would test and the firewall for my computer is completely off

Okay, what’s the output of the following command when the server is running?:

Literally nothing

Really? The server is running, and connected to the internet, and the rs server is running? Did you run it as admin?

Everything is running and i’m on the server with a client (locally). I did try as admin and it didn’t matter. What else should I try? Or perhaps it’s working and I should try the client on another computer?
[/quote]

What that command does is it looks at all the incoming/outgoing connections, and finds the ports they’re all using, and what process is using it. If that command didn’t print anything, that means the no process is currently using port 43594, incoming or outgoing.

Just to clarify, did you run the command on the client, or on the server machine?[/quote]
I’m definitely running the server because I have a client logged in locally. All I did was run that command in a cmd prompt.

Read full topic

item.title: I feel dumb
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“marcbob, post:34, topic:547423”][quote author=Zymus link=topic=666328.msg4458841#msg4458841 date=1416426791]

Are you checking via http://canyouseeme.org/ ?

Yes that’s what I’m using

With any of these checkers, it tries to make a connection to the server that’s running. If the server isn’t running, it will always fail. So that’s what I would check. After that, make sure that you added a firewall rule to allow incoming connections on the correct port for the java process as well.

The server was always running when I would test and the firewall for my computer is completely off

Okay, what’s the output of the following command when the server is running?:

Literally nothing

Really? The server is running, and connected to the internet, and the rs server is running? Did you run it as admin?
[/quote]
Everything is running and i’m on the server with a client (locally). I did try as admin and it didn’t matter. What else should I try? Or perhaps it’s working and I should try the client on another computer?[/quote]

What that command does is it looks at all the incoming/outgoing connections, and finds the ports they’re all using, and what process is using it. If that command didn’t print anything, that means the no process is currently using port 43594, incoming or outgoing.

Just to clarify, did you run the command on the client, or on the server machine?

Read full topic

item.title: I feel dumb
item.dc:creator: @marcbob marcbob
item.description:
@marcbob wrote:

[quote=“matzie, post:24, topic:547423”][quote author=marcbob link=topic=666328.msg4458714#msg4458714 date=1416349248]

I also can’t get my port to open for my server so you are not alone. It is very frustrating. I’m using d-link as well. I’ve made the exceptions turned off my firewall and everything. It just won’t work lol.

I don’t think it’s d-link at this point for me because I did try my linksys and it was not working either. I think it’s something to do with the internet i’m getting. I might as well suck it up and try and find a really cheap vps
[/quote]

Linksys has a little bugger you have to click i know this…

Make sure it is unchecked.[/quote]
Didn’t make it work but it was a good idea I even turned on DMZ and that didn’t work.

Jmood:

I was going to post a couple days ago saying check with your ISP to see if they block ports and what ports they block.

Do you really think they’d block 43594 though? And I googled how to check and can’t find anything

Read full topic

item.title: I feel dumb
item.dc:creator: @marcbob marcbob
item.description:
@marcbob wrote:

[quote=“malimt, post:19, topic:547423”]Is the Wi-Fi Firewall off as well? Because, I remember, I had to turn it off on mine before it finally opened the port.
However,
Did you also allow the Ports TCP/UDP through your firewall?
Let us know, so we can further assist you.[/quote]
The wifi firewall isn’t off but it doesn’t look like it would be the problem. The firewall on the computer is off.

I just tried a router that I have used at my house to successfully portforward and it didn’t work here. There has to be something wrong with the internet i’m using that is blocking it or something.

Read full topic

(its free for 1 year)

Is the Wi-Fi Firewall off as well? Because, I remember, I had to turn it off on mine before it finally opened the port.
However,
Did you also allow the Ports TCP/UDP through your firewall?
Let us know, so we can further assist you.

Read full topic
